en: Letter from T. S. Maxey, judge of the United States District Court for the Western District of Texas, to Professor Louis L. McInnis expressing gratitude for an honor conferred by a university, likely an academic appointment or honorary degree. Maxey acknowledges the compliment with appreciation and reflects on his ties to Mississippi and Texas, expressing his commitment to fulfilling his official duties faithfully. The letter indicates that formal official notification of the honor is expected shortly.

United States District Court,
WESTERN DISTRICT OF TEXAS.

T. S. Maxey
[crossed-out: E. B. TURNER, Judge.]

Austin, Texas, July 10th 1888.

Prof. Louis L. McInnis
Forest, Miss.
My Dear Sir & Friend
The intelligence conveyed by
your valued favor of the 2d inst, was
quite surprising to me, and the more
so because I so little deserve the
honor, which the University has con-
ferred. It is, however, an honor and a
compliment, which I prize very highly
and one, which rekindles, within my heart,
my fervent love for the old state of my
nativity. Mississippi, like Texas, has
ever been more generous than just to
me, and I earnestly pray that it may
be my good fortune, by devotion to duty
and a faithful discharge of my official
trust, to merit the confidence that both
have so liberally [illegible] reposed. Official
notification has not yet been received, but
